to be greater than 0 for all values of x.
Step 1. Write f(x) in standard form:
Step 2. Since the coefficient of x² is 1 (which is positive), the quadratic will be positive for all x if it has no real roots. This is true when its discriminant is negative.
Step 4. For f(x) > 0 for all x, the discriminant must be strictly negative:
This inequality holds when k is between –3 and 5:

Step 5. Finally, check the endpoints. When k = –3 or k = 5 the discriminant is zero, which would cause the quadratic to be a perfect square and take the value 0 for one x. Since we require f(x) > 0 for all x, these endpoint values must be excluded.
Therefore, the quadratic is positive for all x if and only if:
